chapter.title: Datafiles
chapter.para: Data Files are external sources of data for your scripts. The lines will get evenly divided up among the agents for use.

caution.para:
Test Data best practice with security in mind:
Before uploading scripts or test data to Intuit Tank be aware that others will potentially have access to this information. This access can be via Tank controller directly or potentially by capturing the http requests going across the network when running tests. For this reason we ask that you do not store, retrieve sensitive data, or save scripts with hard coded credentials in Intuit Tank. This could include real customer data (PII), trade secrets, employee data, etc. If you have a need to use such data please contact your information security team for guidance before uploading to Intuit Tank. Just for clarification Intuit Tank does encrypt data when storing to S3 and encrypts at rest to the Intuit Tank database.

chapter.para: Clicking the Data Files tab takes the user to the main screen, which lists all the previously created Data Files.

Currently, Intuit Tank supports data files with CSV (Comma Separated Values), and XML format only. The data file is read into shared memory only once, even if it is read by multiple virtual users. Usually you will use one of the functions below only once in your script for each file you load. The following two functions can be used in Intuit Tank to read a file:

listitem.para: This function is used to read a default data file associated with the project. A Data File is default if there is only one in a particular job.

This function can be used to read a specific data file when you have to read from multiple data files used for the same script or multiple scripts in a project (i.e. separate data files for personal information and login credentials).

note.para: Column Number 0 represents the 1st column in the file.

tip.para: It is important that all the user data files needed by your test script are added to your project.

chapter.para: Clicking on the magnify icon will allow you to see the contents of the data file.

listitem.para: In the Data Files Tab, click the Upload link to add data files. The Upload Data Files dialog box opens.

From the Upload Data Files dialog box, click Choose to navigate to and select the data file(s) or zip archives to add to the project. If a zip archive is uploaded, Intuit Tank will recursively upload all files with the ".csv" extension.
Click either Upload or the arrow next to the box to upload the data file. You can also click the cancel button if you choose not to upload the data file.
